attributes.title: Voter evaluations of candidate socioeconomic characteristics

q1.value: Voter evaluations of candidate socioeconomic characteristics

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: How do voters evaluate the socioeconomic characteristics of political candidates, such as occupational and educational attainment? The first part of this study investigates whether voters are biased against working-class and less-educated candidates. The second part examines whether voters use socioeconomic characteristics as heuristics for two important valence qualities: “competence” and “character”.

q16.value: This study combines a conjoint candidate choice design with a priming experiment. The quantities of interest are the average marginal component effects (AMCEs) of candidate attributes, as well as interactions with other attributes and with respondent-level variables. The hypotheses are listed in full in the pre-analysis plan.

q17.value: Survey respondents will rate a series of pairs of candidate profiles. The quantities of interest can be estimated via linear regression (with appropriate adjustments to account for profile restrictions). All results will be presented graphically with point estimates and 95% confidence intervals. Standard errors will be clustered at the respondent level.

attributes.title: Where do politicians engage in gender discrimination? Evidence from North America

q1.value: Where do politicians engage in gender discrimination? Evidence from North America

q2.value: Michelangelo Landgrave | Beyzanur Han Tuncez | John Burnett | Stephen El-Khatib

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: We are interested in better understanding when politicians, operationalized as state/provincial legislators in north America (Canada, the US, and Mexico), engage in discrimination. To do so we will conduct an audit study on August 2018. State/provincial legislators will receive an email asking help from a constituent either searching for information about becoming involved in a civic organization or health services offered by the state. Constituent aliases will either signify a purportedly male or female constituent. There are a total of eight conditions; 2 (civic org or health services question) x 2 (base or gendered) x 2 (male or female constituent.

q16.value: We are interested to test if (a) across treatment conditions, females are discriminated against, (b) if females are discriminated against in the civic organization treatment condition, (c) if females are discriminated against in the health services treatment condition, (d) if degree of discrimination differs by whether a service request is gender neutral or feminine, (e) if female legislators discriminate in favor of female constituents, and (f) if there is a difference between how US-Canadian legislators and Mexican legislators respond. We hypothesize that gender discrimination in the US/Canada is driven largely by different informational availability between male and female legislators. We build upon an earlier audit study by Dan Butler which found that female legislators were more likely than their male counterparts to respond to feminine constituent requests. This is not due to different preferences towards constituents so much as female legislators knowing more about the feminine issues. We hypothesize that gender discrimination in Mexico is driven largely by sexism. Unlike US/Canada, we argue that gender relations in Mexico encourage sexism among legislators. If this is the case, we should find that female constituents are discriminated against both in gender neutral and feminine constituent requests. Additionally we should find that discrimination in Mexico is, overall, higher than discrimination in US/Canada. A supplementary analysis we hope to conduct is to exploit Mexico's multi-member legislative districts to test if discrimination is driven by the preference of legislators or their electoral districts.

q17.value: Primary analysis will consist of comparing email response rates across conditions.

q18.value: Canada, United States of America, Mexico

attributes.title: Experimental Evaluation of the Immigration-to-Welfare Hypothesis

q1.value: Experimental Evaluation of the Immigration-to-Welfare Hypothesis

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Prior research asserts that Americans’ opinions about welfare are anchored in anti-immigrant sentiment. If public opinion about welfare is “immigrationized,” evaluations of foreign-born hypothetical welfare recipients should be more predictive than evaluations of native-born hypothetical welfare recipients of general attitudes about welfare. Earlier work by Martin Gilens (1999) used an analogous experimental format to assess the racialization of welfare.

q16.value: There is a significant and positive interaction between evaluations of a hypothetical welfare recipient and assignment to treatment (whether the hypothetical recipient is an immigrant or U.S. born). This positive interaction would signify that evaluations of a hypothetical immigrant welfare recipient are more predictive than evaluations of a hypothetical U.S.-born welfare recipient of general opinions about welfare.

q17.value: Respondents are assigned at random with equal probability to read a short vignette about a mother who is currently on welfare. All details of the vignette are held constant except that respondents in the control condition read that the mother is “born in the U.S.” whereas those in the treatment condition read that the mother “is an immigrant.” Three dependent variables are constructed, each measuring general opinions about welfare (see pre-analysis plan and survey instrument for details). These dependent variables are analyzed in multivariate ordinary least squares models (for description of covariates, again see pre-analysis plan and survey instrument).

registration_responses.q1: Experimental Evaluation of the Immigration-to-Welfare Hypothesis
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities
registration_responses.q15: Prior research asserts that Americans’ opinions about welfare are anchored in anti-immigrant sentiment. If public opinion about welfare is “immigrationized,” evaluations of foreign-born hypothetical welfare recipients should be more predictive than evaluations of native-born hypothetical welfare recipients of general attitudes about welfare. Earlier work by Martin Gilens (1999) used an analogous experimental format to assess the racialization of welfare.

This positive interaction would signify that evaluations of a hypothetical immigrant welfare recipient are more predictive than evaluations of a hypothetical U.S.-born welfare recipient of general opinions about welfare.
registration_responses.q17: Respondents are assigned at random with equal probability to read a short vignette about a mother who is currently on welfare. All details of the vignette are held constant except that respondents in the control condition read that the mother is “born in the U.S.” whereas those in the treatment condition read that the mother “is an immigrant.” Three dependent variables are constructed, each measuring general opinions about welfare (see pre-analysis plan and survey instrument for details). These dependent variables are analyzed in multivariate ordinary least squares models (for description of covariates, again see pre-analysis plan and survey instrument).

q2.value: Jacob Kopas | Erin Ashley York | S.P. Harish | Shiran Victoria Shen

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Air pollution is an invisible killer that is globally responsible for more deaths can AIDS and malaria combined. Given the highly salient and serious impacts of air pollution on public health and well-being, elected officials should be responsive to public opinion and grievances related to air quality. However, concerted policy responses to this grave situation have been complicated by personal experience and the multi-causal nature of air pollution in India. With that in mind, we seek to address a set of key theoretical questions relating to citizen perceptions regarding pollution and local government. First, how are citizens' perceptions of government impacted by the level of air quality they experience on a daily basis? Second, does information about the sources of air pollution make it easier for citizens to hold government officials accountable for their policies?

q16.value: Hypothesis 1a Exposure to lower levels of air pollution is associated with lower perceptions of air quality. Hypothesis 1b Exposure to lower levels of air pollution is associated with higher opinions about air pollution. Hypothesis 1c Exposure to lower levels of air pollution is associated with lower levels of social trust. Hypothesis 1d Exposure to lower levels of air pollution is associated with higher levels of con fidence in the state government. Hypothesis 1e Exposure to lower levels of air pollution is associated with higher levels of con fidence in the central government. Hypothesis 2a Information about the quality of air pollution will increase the rank of air pollution compared to other social issues. Hypothesis 2b Information about the quality of air pollution will decrease con fidence government to respond to the problem. Hypothesis 2c Information about the causes of air pollution will increase the rank of air pollution compared to other social issues. Hypothesis 2d Information about the causes of air pollution will decrease con fidence government to respond to the problem. Hypothesis 2e Information about the quality and causes of air pollution will increase the rank of air pollution compared to other social issues. Hypothesis 2f Information about the quality and causes of air pollution will decrease con fidence government to respond to the problem. Hypothesis 3a When respondents are given information on the increased cost to the common man to solve the problem of air pollution, it should decrease their con fidence in government. Hypothesis 3b When respondents are given information on the increased cost to powerful people to solve the problem of air pollution, it should decrease their confi dence in government.

q17.value: We conduct the experiment in the city of Lucknow, India. With an area of 2,500 sq km, the city is divided into 110 wards. We identi fied the population of these wards and randomly sampled (with replacement) a total of 300 wards from them.2 The selection probability is based on the relative population of these wards. We use an experienced survey enumerator from Morsel, a survey company based in Lucknow, to perform the data collection. The enumerator was trained by one of the authors in the  field during the piloting process. Data is collected using a survey instrument included in Supplementary Materials. Each day, the enumerator will go to the randomly chosen ward and survey 5 people. The survey will be conducted  ve days of the week save for any public holidays. So, in total, we will conduct 1,500 surveys over the course of a year. With this sampling strategy, we expect a sample that will be geographically representative of the city of Lucknow. The survey will be conducted face-to-face and the data will be collected electronically via a tablet.

attributes.title: The effects of the 2016 Presidential election and related immigration policies and enforcement actions on health care utilization among undocumented immigrants in the San Francisco Bay Area

q1.value: The effects of the 2016 Presidential election and related immigration policies and enforcement actions on health care utilization among undocumented immigrants in the San Francisco Bay Area

q2.value: Jacqueline Torres | Jens Hainmueller | Michael Hotard | Duncan Lawrence | Vasil Yasenov

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: We will analyze the effect of the 2016 Presidential election, the passage of immigration-related legislature and some local migration enforcement events in 2017 and 2018 on health care utilization among immigrants in two San Francisco Bay Area regions.

q16.value: We expect to observe lower health care utilization rates immediately after the events of interest among likely undocumented patients. We also expect increases in emergency room visits and/or hospital admissions for ambulatory care sensitive conditions for the same group. At the same time, we predict no significant differences in health care usage among likely documented patients. We hypothesize there could be some spillover effects to documented individuals of Hispanic origin.

q17.value: We will compare the rate of health care utilization around the events of interest among possibly undocumented individuals with otherwise similar but likely documented ones. We will use information on available personal characteristics such as age, gender, race and spoken language to create the control groups. Methodologically, besides analyzing the raw data, we will use a panel fixed effects framework and possibly a regression discontinuity design.

attributes.title: Public Opposition to Human Rights Adjudication in National and European Courts

q1.value: Public Opposition to Human Rights Adjudication in National and European Courts

q2.value: Mikael Rask Madsen | Juan Mayoral | Anton Strezhnev | Erik Voeten

q5.value: We thankfully acknowledge useful comments from participants at the iCourts Power of International Courts conference, in Copenhagen (May 20-21, 2019) and the Law and Society Annual Meeting (Washington DC), and the 2019 American Political Science Association annual meeting (Washington DC). We thank Soetkin Verhaegen, Kenneth Scheve, and Mike Tomz for useful comments and suggestions. This experiment was reviewed and approved by the Georgetown University Institutional Review Board, ID: STUDY00000475.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Do people become less willing to accept a court ruling that protects the rights of an unsympathetic individual if it comes about through an international court overruling a national court? Public opposition to international courts can stem from procedural preferences for national over international institutions and from more substantive concerns over the outcomes of rulings. In practice, these two motivations may be difficult to disentangle. Opposition to international human rights protections may originate in sovereignty concerns as well as a dislike for protecting individuals deemed unworthy. Yet, these motivations are conceptually distinct and have different implications for the legitimacy of international and national courts. We design a series of survey experiments in five European countries (Denmark, France, Poland, Spain, and the United Kingdom) to assess which of these two factors better explains resistance to international courts.

q16.value: We develop a series of survey experiments involving vignettes that describe a hypothetical case evaluated by both a national and international court. The vignettes vary whether an international court overrules a national court (subsidiarity treatment) and whether an applicant wins the case (outcome treatment). In the primary vignette, the applicant, a foreign criminal, is unsympathetic to most people but especially to right-wing authoritarians, who have been most critical of international courts and liberal institutions more generally. The other vignettes include applicants that are more sympathetic to the authoritarian right (an individual who burns Korans) or the left (a tenant who is evicted). We have two main effect hypotheses for each of these vignettes: H1 (Sovereignty/Subsidiarity effect): Support is lower if the European court disagrees with the national court. H2 (Outcome effect): Support is lower if an unsympathetic applicant, such as a foreign criminal, wins the case (or a sympathetic applicant loses a case). We also posit possible heterogeneous treatment effects of the subsidiarity treatment based on respondents’ prior attitudes towards their domestic legal system and their nationalist/right-wing authoritarian beliefs. H3a (Procedural heterogeneity: satisfaction with legal system): Perceived sovereignty costs increase the more satisfied an individual is with the domestic legal system. H3b (Procedural heterogeneity: nationalism): Perceived sovereignty costs increase the more nationalist an individual is. H3c (Procedural heterogeneity: right-wing authoritarianism): Perceived sovereignty costs increase the more authoritarian an individual’s values are. We likewise wish to test for treatment effect heterogeneity of the outcome treatment with respect to attitudes towards the applicant and nationalist/right-wing authoritarian values. H4a (Outcome heterogeneity: preferences): Individuals who value the applicant’s rights unfavourably are less likely to support a court (ruling) that favors the applicant. H3b (Outcome heterogeneity: nationalism): Support for a court (ruling) will vary depending on the how nationalist an individual is. H3c (Outcome heterogeneity: right-wing authoritarianism): Support for a court (ruling) will vary depending on the how authoritarian an individual’s values are.

q17.value: For the main effect hypotheses (H1 and H2), we will estimate the average effect of each treatment and test against the null hypothesis of no effect using a conventional t-test with a rejection alpha of .05. For the effect moderation hypotheses, we first will interact the treatment with the moderating covariate (binary) and assess whether the difference in treatment effects for different levels of the covariate is statistically distinguishable from zero (at a rejection alpha of .05). In all cases, to improve power, we will post-stratify our sample on prognostic covariates: age, gender, level of education, and survey country.

q18.value: United Kingdom, Denmark, France, Spain, Poland

This experiment was reviewed and approved by the Georgetown University Institutional Review Board, ID: STUDY00000475.

attributes.title: Majority size, issue salience, and public support for court decisions: Evidence from a survey-embedded vignette experiment

q1.value: Majority size, issue salience, and public support for court decisions: Evidence from a survey-embedded vignette experiment

q2.value: Henrik Litleré Bentsen | Sveinung Arnesen | Jon Kåre Skiple

q5.value: This experimental study is part of the Research Council of Norway’s project number 262986: “Can Fair Decision-Making Procedures Increase the Legitimacy of Democracies?”

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Does judicial dissent influence public support for court decisions? The conventional wisdom is that unanimous rulings boost support for court decisions, while dissent fuels popular opposition. However, an alternative hypothesis suggests that dissent might have a positive influence on public support by suggesting evidence of procedural justice. Existing literature examining the relationship between dissent and public support has provided empirical evidence for both theoretical claims. However, a common finding in the literature is that the extent to which dissent either harm or boost public support depends on the salience of the issue treated by the court. Yet, despite the important moderating effect of issue salience, this concept has not been adequately accounted for in existing literature. Until now, researchers have labelled policy issues as high salience, medium salience or low salience, thus assuming that salience is uniform across individuals. This is a strong assumption to make, as we should expect issue salience to vary between individuals for each issue area. In other words, the question of issue salience is an empirical question that should be asked directly to the respondents. This study experimentally investigates issue salience as moderator on how dissent influences public support for court decisions using the experimental subjects’ self-reported importance of the issue in question. This is in line with recommendations in the literature that issue salience should be treated as a political attitude like any other, and not just as a behavioral weight as defined by researchers ex-ante. As such, the proposed study contributes with a more precise examination of how issue salience moderates the extent to which procedural and outcome-related aspects of a court decision influences public support of a given decision.

q16.value: The study examines six hypotheses. The pro-unanimity hypothesis (H1) states that unanimity will increase support for court decisions. In other words, any dissent at all should be harmful to public support. The anti-division hypothesis (H2) states that that closely divided decisions will decrease support because they indicate that public policy outcomes may hang solely on the political attitudes of the median justice. In contrast to the pro-unanimity hypothesis, the anti-division hypothesis argues that larger, non-unanimous majorities mainly influence public support negatively. Finally, the procedural justice hypothesis (H3) argues that dissent might have a positive influence on public support. When individuals see evidence of debate in court (as shown by dissenting opinions), they might interpret this as a result of a fair, democratic decision-making process in which both sides were heard. The issue salience hypothesis (H4) states the degree to which judicial dissent may influence public opinion depend on the salience of the issue at hand. In short, dissent should not move opinion on high salience ("hot-button") issues, but it might do so on issues of medium or low salience where opinions are not as crystallized. The outcome favorability hypothesis (H5) argues that outcome favorability will influence the extent to which unanimity and dissent influences public support. Whereas winners will ordinarily accept a decision with which they agree, losers should be more inclined to make evaluations of procedural fairness when they decide whether to support a decision or not. Accordingly, among the political opponents of a court decision, we expect a unanimous decision to receive a lower level of support compared to their baseline level of support, whereas dissenting decisions should receive a higher level of support. Finally, the diffuse support hypothesis (H6) argues that the extent to which unanimity and dissent influences public support depend on individuals’ levels of diffuse support for the court. Specifically, we assume that those with low faith in the institution would generally have a lower likelihood of accepting the court’s decisions and that this should be true regardless of whether the decision is unanimous or dissenting.

q17.value: The hypotheses are tested through a survey-embedded vignette experiment using a nationally representative sample of Norway's population. The experiment asks respondents to read and evaluate a short vignette about a fictitious Supreme Court decision. The decision is based on a case treated in the Oslo lower court in 2017 where Greenpeace and Nature and Youth petitioned the Norwegian government to halt further searching for oil in the Barents Sea. The government won the case, which is now subject for review in the Court of Appeals. In the experiment, we ask respondents to imagine that this particular case reaches the Supreme Court. In the vignette presenting the fictitious Supreme Court decision on this case, the size of the majority and the outcome of the decision in randomized. In addition, the experiment is designed to capture whether the influence of unanimity and dissent on public support is moderated (1) by the subjects' self reported importance of the issue in question, (2) by whether subjects are given a favorable or an unfavorable policy outcome relative to their pretreatment attitudes toward the issue, and (3) by the subjects' stated levels of diffuse support for the Supreme Court.

q27.value: Ideas2Evidence will administer the survey on behalf of the Norwegian Citizen Panel

registration_responses.q1: Majority size, issue salience, and public support for court decisions: Evidence from a survey-embedded vignette experiment
registration_responses.q2: Henrik Litleré Bentsen | Sveinung Arnesen | Jon Kåre Skiple
registration_responses.q5: This experimental study is part of the Research Council of Norway’s project number 262986: “Can Fair Decision-Making Procedures Increase the Legitimacy of Democracies?”
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data
registration_responses.q15: Does judicial dissent influence public support for court decisions? The conventional wisdom is that unanimous rulings boost support for court decisions, while dissent fuels popular opposition. However, an alternative hypothesis suggests that dissent might have a positive influence on public support by suggesting evidence of procedural justice. Existing literature examining the relationship between dissent and public support has provided empirical evidence for both theoretical claims. However, a common finding in the literature is that the extent to which dissent either harm or boost public support depends on the salience of the issue treated by the court. Yet, despite the important moderating effect of issue salience, this concept has not been adequately accounted for in existing literature. Until now, researchers have labelled policy issues as high salience, medium salience or low salience, thus assuming that salience is uniform across individuals. This is a strong assumption to make, as we should expect issue salience to vary between individuals for each issue area. In other words, the question of issue salience is an empirical question that should be asked directly to the respondents. This study experimentally investigates issue salience as moderator on how dissent influences public support for court decisions using the experimental subjects’ self-reported importance of the issue in question. This is in line with recommendations in the literature that issue salience should be treated as a political attitude like any other, and not just as a behavioral weight as defined by researchers ex-ante. As such, the proposed study contributes with a more precise examination of how issue salience moderates the extent to which procedural and outcome-related aspects of a court decision influences public support of a given decision.
registration_responses.q16: The study examines six hypotheses. The pro-unanimity hypothesis (H1) states that unanimity will increase support for court decisions. In other words, any dissent at all should be harmful to public support. The anti-division hypothesis (H2) states that that closely divided decisions will decrease support because they indicate that public policy outcomes may hang solely on the political attitudes of the median justice. In contrast to the pro-unanimity hypothesis, the anti-division hypothesis argues that larger, non-unanimous majorities mainly influence public support negatively. Finally, the procedural justice hypothesis (H3) argues that dissent might have a positive influence on public support. When individuals see evidence of debate in court (as shown by dissenting opinions), they might interpret this as a result of a fair, democratic decision-making process in which both sides were heard. The issue salience hypothesis (H4) states the degree to which judicial dissent may influence public opinion depend on the salience of the issue at hand. In short, dissent should not move opinion on high salience ("hot-button") issues, but it might do so on issues of medium or low salience where opinions are not as crystallized. The outcome favorability hypothesis (H5) argues that outcome favorability will influence the extent to which unanimity and dissent influences public support. Whereas winners will ordinarily accept a decision with which they agree, losers should be more inclined to make evaluations of procedural fairness when they decide whether to support a decision or not. Accordingly, among the political opponents of a court decision, we expect a unanimous decision to receive a lower level of support compared to their baseline level of support, whereas dissenting decisions should receive a higher level of support. Finally, the diffuse support hypothesis (H6) argues that the extent to which unanimity and dissent influences public support depend on individuals’ levels of diffuse support for the court. Specifically, we assume that those with low faith in the institution would generally have a lower likelihood of accepting the court’s decisions and that this should be true regardless of whether the decision is unanimous or dissenting.
registration_responses.q17: The hypotheses are tested through a survey-embedded vignette experiment using a nationally representative sample of Norway's population. The experiment asks respondents to read and evaluate a short vignette about a fictitious Supreme Court decision. The decision is based on a case treated in the Oslo lower court in 2017 where Greenpeace and Nature and Youth petitioned the Norwegian government to halt further searching for oil in the Barents Sea. The government won the case, which is now subject for review in the Court of Appeals. In the experiment, we ask respondents to imagine that this particular case reaches the Supreme Court. In the vignette presenting the fictitious Supreme Court decision on this case, the size of the majority and the outcome of the decision in randomized. In addition, the experiment is designed to capture whether the influence of unanimity and dissent on public support is moderated (1) by the subjects' self reported importance of the issue in question, (2) by whether subjects are given a favorable or an unfavorable policy outcome relative to their pretreatment attitudes toward the issue, and (3) by the subjects' stated levels of diffuse support for the Supreme Court.
registration_responses.q27: Ideas2Evidence will administer the survey on behalf of the Norwegian Citizen Panel

attributes.title: Public Opinion on the Use of Nuclear Weapons

q1.value: Public Opinion on the Use of Nuclear Weapons

q2.value: Tyler Bowen | Michael Goldfien | Matthew H Graham

q5.value: The authors would like to thank Alex Coppock, Alexandre Debs, and Nuno Monteiro for their generous support of this project.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: We build on earlier studies investigating public attitudes on the use of nuclear weapons using an experimental design. Our design builds on that used by Press, Sagan, and Valentino (2013). We expand the number of scenarios presented to subjects by varying more attributes of potential military strikes. In doing so, we are better able to study how contextual or background factors condition public attitudes on the use of nuclear weapon, and can thus provide a more comprehensive experimental assessment of nuclear aversion and taboo arguments than has been done previously.

q17.value: Our design has three parts: • A 2 x 2 survey experiment. • A choice experiment in which the randomization is restricted such that only realistic choices between nuclear and conventional weapons. • A conjoint experiment in which strike attributes are fully randomized. The pre-analysis plan describes the statistical tests we will perform.
